metadata.title: Future Forms: Plans and Predictions
metadata.topic: Grammar: Will, Going to, Present Continuous for future
metadata.keywords: future, plans, predictions, will, going-to, intentions

objectives.objective: Use 'going to' to talk about plans and intentions
Use 'will' for spontaneous decisions and predictions
Understand the difference between planned and unplanned future

stage.name: Lead-in
stage.description:
Ask a somatic grounding question: "Close your eyes for a moment and imagine tomorrow morning. What's the first thing you see yourself doing? Notice how your body responds to thinking about the future - maybe your shoulders relax, or your breath deepens. The future starts in our imagination."
Then transition: "Today we're going to learn how to talk about the future in English - your plans, your dreams, and your predictions."

stage.name: Pre task A (Activate)
stage.description:
Elicit prior knowledge about future plans using Socratic questions. Use carousel for options:
Card 1: "What are you planning to do this weekend?" Card 2: "What's one goal you have for this year?" Card 3: "Where do you see yourself in five years?"
Follow up with deeper questions: - "How did you decide on that plan?" - "What makes you excited about it?" - "What might change your plans?"
Listen for how they express future ideas - they might use present tense ("I go shopping tomorrow") or mixed forms. Don't correct yet, just notice.

stage.name: Pre task B (Model)

dialogue.title: Making Weekend Plans
dialogue.context: Two colleagues, Sara and Ahmed, are talking on Friday afternoon about their weekend plans.
dialogue.speaker: So, what are you going to do this weekend, Ahmed?
I'm going to visit my parents on Saturday. We're going to have a big family dinner. What about you?
I'm not sure yet. I'll probably stay home and relax. Oh wait - it's going to rain tomorrow, I just checked the weather.
Really? Then I'll bring an umbrella. Are you going to do anything on Sunday?
Yes! I'm meeting some friends for brunch. We're going to try that new café downtown. Want to join us?
That sounds great! Sure, I'll come! What time are you meeting?
We're meeting at 11. I'll send you the address later.

stage.conceptChecks:
After presenting the dialogue, ask: - "What is Ahmed's plan for Saturday?" (Visit parents - he decided this before) - "Did Sara plan to stay home?" (No, she just decided now) - "How do they know it's going to rain?" (Weather prediction - evidence) - "Notice Ahmed says 'I'll bring an umbrella' - when did he decide this?" (Right now, spontaneous) - "When Sara says 'I'm meeting friends' - is this a plan or a spontaneous decision?" (A plan, already arranged)
Use notice boxes to highlight the different forms they're using.

grammarFocus.structure: Three ways to talk about the future
grammarFocus.explanation:
Present the grammar using CARD layout:
**Card 1: GOING TO (for plans and intentions)**
Form: am/is/are + going to + base verb
Use when: - You already decided/planned something - You have evidence for a prediction
Examples: - "I'm going to study tonight." (I already decided) - "Look at those clouds - it's going to rain!" (I can see evidence) - "They're going to move to Canada next year." (They already made this plan)
**Card 2: WILL (for spontaneous decisions and predictions)**
Form: will + base verb
Use when: - You decide something right now (spontaneous) - You're making a prediction without evidence - You're offering, promising, or refusing
Examples: Spontaneous: "I'm thirsty. I'll get some water." (deciding now) Prediction: "I think it will be sunny tomorrow." (opinion/guess) Offer: "Don't worry, I'll help you!" (promise)
**Card 3: PRESENT CONTINUOUS (for fixed arrangements)**
Form: am/is/are + verb-ing
Use when: - You have a fixed arrangement with specific time/place - Usually with time expressions
Examples: - "I'm meeting John at 3pm." (We arranged this) - "We're flying to Paris on Monday." (We booked tickets) - "She's having dinner with her boss tomorrow." (Specific arrangement)
**Card 4: Comparison - Use notice box:**
"I'm going to see a movie." → I decided earlier, general plan "I'm seeing a movie at 7pm at Cinema 5." → Fixed arrangement, specific details "I'll see a movie." → Just decided now, spontaneous
**Card 5: Questions**
Going to: "What are you going to do?" Will: "What will happen next?" Present Continuous: "What are you doing tomorrow?"
**Card 6: Negatives**
Going to: "I'm not going to quit." Will: "It won't rain." Present Continuous: "I'm not working tomorrow."
grammarFocus.examples:
Provide multiple examples using learning cards with context:
- "A: The phone is ringing. B: I'll answer it!" (spontaneous offer) - "I'm going to learn Spanish next year. I already bought the textbook." (plan with evidence) - "We're having a team meeting on Thursday at 10am." (fixed arrangement) - "I think robots will do more jobs in the future." (prediction, no evidence) - "Look at the time! We're going to be late!" (prediction with evidence)

pronunciationFocus.feature: Reduction of "going to" → "gonna" in connected speech
pronunciationFocus.guidance:
Use think prompts: "Listen to how native speakers say 'going to' in casual conversation..."
**Focus areas:**
1. **Reduction: going to → gonna** /ˈɡɒnə/ - "I'm going to study" → "I'm gonna study" - "They're going to arrive late" → "They're gonna arrive late"
Note in dialogue box: "In informal speech, 'going to' sounds like 'gonna'. This is normal! But we still write 'going to'."
2. **Will contraction** + weak form: - I will → I'll /aɪl/ - You will → You'll /juːl/ - It will → It'll /ˈɪtl/ (very weak)
3. **Won't** /woʊnt/: - "Will not" → "Won't" (notice the /o/ sound, not /ɪ/)
4. **Connected speech**: - "I'll see you" → "I'll-see-you" (flows together) - "What are you going to do?" → "Whadda-ya-gonna-do?" (very casual)
Model examples, then ask student to repeat naturally: - "I'm gonna call my mom tonight." - "I'll text you later." - "What're you gonna do this weekend?"

taskSetup.scenario: Imagine you and a friend are planning an exciting weekend trip together. You need to decide what you're going to do, where you'll go, and make spontaneous decisions along the way.
taskSetup.roles:
Assign roles: - Student: One friend making suggestions and plans - You (Nour): The other friend, asking questions and also making spontaneous decisions
Provide thinking time: "Take 30 seconds to think about: What kind of trip do you want? Beach? Mountains? City? What activities sound fun?"
taskSetup.support:
Provide sentence stems carousel:
**For plans (going to):** - "I'm going to ___" - "We're going to ___ and then ___" - "I'm not going to ___ because ___"
**For spontaneous decisions (will):** - "I'll ___ if you ___" - "Don't worry, I'll ___" - "I think I'll ___"
**For arrangements (present continuous):** - "I'm ___ at [time]" - "We're meeting ___ at ___"
Vocabulary support carousel: - Activities: swimming, hiking, sightseating, trying local food, taking photos, relaxing - Places: beach, mountains, museum, market, café, hotel - Time: this weekend, tomorrow morning, next Saturday, at 9am

activity.description:
Facilitate a natural planning conversation. Start with:
"So, exciting! We're planning a weekend trip. Where are we going to go?"
As the conversation progresses, create opportunities for different future forms: - Ask about pre-made plans: "What are you going to do on Saturday?" - Create spontaneous moments: "Oh no, I forgot my camera!" → Student might say "I'll lend you mine!" - Ask about specific arrangements: "What time are we meeting the guide?"
Monitor for these common errors WITHOUT interrupting: - Using 'will' for plans: "I will visit my parents tomorrow" (should be 'going to' if it's a plan) - Using 'going to' for spontaneous: "Oh! I'm going to help you!" (should be 'will') - Wrong form: "I'm go to study" instead of "I'm going to study"
Encourage extended conversation. Let them make decisions together, change plans, predict weather, etc.

stage.name: Reporting
stage.reflection:
Use self-assessment widget:
"How confident do you feel about the different future forms now?"
Ask metacognitive questions: - "Which form felt easiest: going to, will, or present continuous?" - "Can you think of a moment where you chose one form over another? Why?" - "What's still a bit confusing?" - "If you were teaching a friend, which form would you explain first?"

stage.name: Feedback
stage.feedbackGuidance:
Focus on 2-3 priority areas using highlights.
Common feedback patterns for A2:
**If they mixed up will/going to:** Use a comparison card with notice box: "When you said 'I will visit my mom tomorrow' - this sounds like you're deciding now. But if you already planned it, we say 'I'm going to visit my mom.' The difference is: Did you already decide? (going to) Or are you deciding right now? (will)"
**If they had trouble with 'gonna' pronunciation:** Use dialogue box to model natural speech, then encourage practice.
**Positive feedback example:** ✨ "You did really well with time expressions! You said 'I'm meeting you at 5pm' - perfect use of present continuous for a fixed arrangement."
**Correction example:** Instead of: "I will go shopping tomorrow." (This sounds unplanned) Better: "I'm going to go shopping tomorrow." (Shows it's a plan)
**Your goal for next time:** Practice listening for these forms in movies or podcasts. When you hear "I'll" - ask yourself: Is this spontaneous? When you hear "going to" - is there a plan?
End with encouragement: "Your planning conversation felt really natural - I could imagine us actually taking that trip together!"

lesson.culturalContext:
Different cultures have different relationships with planning and spontaneity. Some students come from cultures where detailed planning is the norm; others are more comfortable with spontaneity. Both are valid! Use this lesson to explore how language reflects these differences.
When students share plans, honor their timeline - whether it's a weekend trip or a five-year goal.

vocabularyBank.word: tomorrow, tonight, next week, this weekend, soon, later, in the future
visit, meet, travel, study, work, relax, try

commonErrors.error: Using 'will' for definite plans: "I will visit" → "I'm going to visit"
Forgetting 'to' after 'going': "I'm going study" → "I'm going to study"
Wrong form of 'be': "I is going to" → "I am going to"
Using 'going to' for spontaneous: "I'm going to help you!" (just decided) → "I'll help you!"
